It's in a converted shipping container along with a couple other businesses right next door, which is really cool. It's got a really cool Soviet theme, which makes this right out of a James Bond flick. If the Russian Premier were to come visit in SF he would get coffee here. It's individually brewed, at a specific temperature and poured over at a specific rate of flow. Like dude I've never seen coffee this individually crafted. Sure it's $5 a pop but bro they make it for you right there. This is the best coffee I've ever had and I've had coffee at just about every shop in the city. Great job guys, I keep coming back because it's the best.
author: Nick B.

description:
Great Customer Service. Delicious Coffee. After the horrible customer service we experienced at Philz in Sausalito, I was glad to see that not all independent coffee houses are elitist. 
The two baristas were friendly and informative. The coffee and latte were delicious.
author: Karena H.

description:
I found this place a couple of weeks after I found the Blue Bottle down the alley, and I've been trying to decide which one I like better. I think Blue Bottle has an edge in espresso, but Ritual is a better place to sit down with a brewed coffee. Both do good pour-overs; I think Ritual uses Hario cones and Blue Bottle uses the Bonmacs with the small holes (easier to use if you want to pick one up for home use). Ritual also offers a rotating selection of single origin brewed coffees and espressos; I haven't noticed similar options at Blue Bottle. Blue Bottle sells smaller bags of beans to take home -- a good thing if it takes you a while to get through a bag.

Try both. Get some ice cream as a palette cleanser. As far as I'm concerned, this is one of the awesomest blocks in San Francisco.
author: Nath A.

description: Good coffee and location. The brew was made kinda lazy but got the job done. After visiting sight glass and four barrel, it's difficult to rate the taste and experience high.
author: Chase L.

description:
Maybe it was the beans I had or maybe my tongue is just fine-tuned to like Blue Bottle more.  Whatever the case, I just wasn't feeling the Ritual drip.  Flavor was ok, just not deep and rich enough for me.  Nothing against the barrista, though I did think it was weird to be told to let my coffee cool down a bit before I add condiments.  Wait, what?  

No worries, there are plenty of others I'm sure will fill my place in line.  They have a good product, just not my cup of...coffee.
author: Maria S.

description:
Not bad. I'll be honest - I'm not crazy about the light-to-medium roasts that they specialize in. The decaf I got was supposed to taste like bananas foster, berry sauce, and some other berry stuff (blackberry pie?). Um, it tasted like coffee. Decent coffee, but wasn't picking up those "notes" at all.

They very, very, very carefully prepared the pourover coffee, and at $3 it was not expensive considering the care they took to make it.

But, really, I'm not sure my coffee needs that much care.
author: Jason M.

description: Solid cup-of-joe. All of the regular coffees are drip/pour-over so expect to wait a few minutes (quality takes time!)
author: Will Z.

description:
A huge YES to this place. YES, they serve amazing coffee. YES, they offer full-sun outdoor seating. YES, the roasts are diverse and exciting. YES, it's located right next to Beirgarten and YES the staff is super cute/friendly/helpful/etc.

Stop by if you're in the neighborhood. You won't regret your decision.
author: Liz W.

description:
When the fog clouds the city sky a good cup of coffee makes it all better.  At least that's what I was going for with ritual being rated one of the top 10 best of the bay area brews. Already slightly caffeinated I went with the decaf espresso. And I don't think this gets ordered much solo... I had to confirm that's all I was having. 

The room expands nicely to fit the seemingly local croud, each consumed by their digital affairs. Love the welcoming decor with a few couches for intimate conversation.

Even the staff seems to be enjoying their time at this space. Def worth the visit, and a bag of coffee to continue the palate pleasure at home ;)
author: Ryan C.

description: Awesome location in Hayes valley right in front of smitten ice cream.  coffee is good, but not my favorite in san francisco.  I really like the location, giving it a very outdoorsy park feeling.  very friendly service as well.
author: Linda T.

description:
Bottom line: I think Ritual Roasters serve great coffee and offer a welcoming atmosphere... to those who like being told what they should drink. But if you like your coffee a certain way - especially if (like me) you prefer 1/2 shot of coffee in your latte because you can't sleep at night otherwise - don't come here.

The whole story: I walked up to the bar and asked for a "light late" (i.e., 1/2 shot). The barrista offered a "large cup with a whole shot instead as a 1/2 shot would compromise the flavor." I said it wouldn't work, as I'd be up all night, and if it would be OK to just give me a shot of coffee, and a cup of milk, and I'll mix them myself. His response? "Sorry, I'm going to have to refuse to serve you." 

You'd think he was working in a genetics lab and running careful PCRs. Anyways, that was the last time I'd ever go there.
author: Jessica A.

description:
2nd time here. Both times were just ok.

This past visit I had an iced coffee. Yea yea, maybe I ordered the wrong thing, but in all honestly, everything should be pretty good at a third wave coffee shop. I got in line, and ordered an iced coffee. $5. Yes, $5. Really? Yes, really. Ok. Fine, I thought to myself. This better be an awesome iced coffee since Blue Bottle is right around the corner and offers their New Orleans one for $3.50.

So I watch the preparation of the iced coffee. Automatic Fail. Hot pour over coffee straight into a cup of ice is just not cutting it. That's actually considered half-assed. While it was better than Starbucks, I doubt I'd ever come here. I will gladly pay my $3.50 and walk to Blue Bottle.

No more Ritual for me.
author: Andy L.

description:
Someone at Ritual must have attended the Rob Gordon School of Business (http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0146882/quotes?qt=qt0377403) because I've walked by here several times on my way to Blue Bottle without even realizing it. Luckily one day scents wafting over from a nearby food truck caught my attention and I stumbled across Ritual.

While it may be served out of some sort of converted shipping container, the cappuccino was just as good as the ones I've had from their Valencia location, and slightly better than the Blue Bottle further down the alley. While I still like Four Barrel's better, this is a solid #2 for "Best cappuccino within a 5 minute walk of my apartment". Man, we are a spoiled bunch here in San Francisco.
author: Mark A.

description:
Bleh!
Their coffee is too sour for me, so is their espresso.
My rating is not based on their service but exclusively on their sour product.
 It is good to have coffee options in Hayes Valley, but Ritual Roasters, I am not a fan.
author: M E.

description: A day before and after going to this location I had Ritual at the location on Valencia, and can definitively say this one wasn't as good, though I did haev a different espresso in my drink here.  That said, they recommended it.  Morale of the story is probably to avoid guest espresso for milk drinks!
author: Craig Z.

description: Ritual serves up VERY good espressos and drip coffees.  Quaintly built into the backside of the Smitten Ice Cream building just off of Hayes @ Octavia, I usually wind up here before/after Off-the-Grid events (and before/after a Smitten Ice Cream).  I'm seldom in Hayes Valley, but I would make a point of stopping here for espresso if in the area.  By the way- the coconut macaroons are excellent as well- be sure to give one a try!
author: Andy S.

description:
Best coffe in SF. Blue Bottle, Sightglass, Trouble, and 4 Barrel all do one thing exceptionally well when it comes to espresso. Ritual offers the variety of the seasons. It's always excellent and always changing. My only gripe is they let that get to them.  If I order a lungo, then don't tell me you can't make it or it's not proper or the beans are only roasted for a ristretto pull.. Just make it they way I ask.  
 The arrogant snobbery really cuts into the sweet aroma making Ritual feel like a cult at times.
author: caleb G.

description: Super flavorful decaf coffee made by baristas working in a very cool setting. Pour over is the name of the game here. Hayes Valley corner has it all - coffee, ice cream, pizza and juice!
author: P G.

description:
Thanks to Cameron and the Kevin for getting up at the crack of dawn to keep all of us coffee lovers warm and happy in the morning. He's a great barista . . . . . makes an amazing latte. 

What a terrific find in the heart of Hayes Valley. Right next to the dog park on Octavia, a nice place to be for some heart-warming coffee and lively conversation.
author: Dirk W.

description:
The Good: Coffee is the real deal. 

The Bad: You wait patiently as they caress your cup of coffee like a new-born child, taking the most ridiculous steps and precautions, to give you the ultimate in hipster coffee experience. 20 minutes later, you have a DRIP coffee that cost $4. It's definitely not worth the money or wait.

If it's the scene you're after, then I guess this is the place for you. If you're after a quick cup of good, reasonably priced coffee, go somewhere else.
author: Trevor K.

description:
I am not a coffee snob.....so this was an educating experience.....

The first thing I want to mention is how sweet both of the baristas were.  I was refreshed by their customer service- answering my questions without making me feel inferior or stupid......"kind hipsters" make any experience magical, these ladies were clearly experts. 

Second, there was nothing bitter about it!  This was new to me, since I was born and raised on Starbucks.  I will never forsake Starbucks, but I did feel much more adult drinking this manicured cup of joe.  I had the mocha, it was frothy and not too sweet.

Third, location.  

Looking forward to returning.....craving another mocha from there right now.
author: Veronica D.

description: I admit I came here mostly because of the nicely designed outdoor kiosk and name recognition. This was one of the only times I've seen an all female staff at a coffee joint. Pretty cool. This location isn't as jam packed popular as the other Valencia location but still rather bustling. The ordering situation is rather cumbersome. Who do I pay? Where do I pick up? Still it's good coffee. I just cannot differentiate what makes Ritual the bees knees as opposed to the bees buzz.
author: Michael H.

description:
First time visiting Ritual yesterday.  Made an out of the way effort to get here and it paid off.  I had the El Renacer Sweet Tooth in a 12oz Americano and it was bright with notes of brown sugar and grapes/cherries - recommended.  Service was nice and attentive, location was right next to the park.  

My only issue with this location was the impossible parking.  I spent about 10-15 minutes circling until I just parked 3 blocks away on Fell between Laguna and Buchanan.  Oh yeah and they don't have any artificial sweetener.  But regardless of these shortcomings, I will definitely be coming back to Ritual.

The 10 Second Takeaway:
+Good espresso w/ good baristas
-Parking
-No Sweetener
author: Ernest Y.

description:
If you're a coffee connoisseur like me, you'll be able to understand and appreciate Ritual.  They take their time (really...like...a whole 10 minutes) to brew your coffee with, oddly enough, the contraption that a Ph.D friend so enthusiastically demonstrated to me back in the day at his place.  Errh, I wasn't taking notes...

They brew a perfect cup of coffee: so much better than Starbucks that I'd be surprised if anyone were to choose that toxic gasoline of a cup to Ritual's.  The perfect caffeine spot for that pick me up while in Hayes Valley.  The backside of the shop is dedicated to ice cream.  Just look for the long line of customers jutting out from a red box like structure.  I'll have to try the ice cream on a hot day in SF.
author: Jenny K.

description:
When I don't feel like waiting in an absurd line for my daily dose of caffeine (Four Barrel, Blue Bottle), this walkup counter is the perfect antidote. There's considerably less pretention here and I'm obsessed with handing over an extra $1 for the Sweet Tooth option cappuccino, which is truly the best option you can order. They have some cute looking baked goods that I haven't yet sampled (how could I, with Miette and Smitten so close by, there's certainly no lack of dessert options in Hayes Valley).

If they could hook up the eco lids that all the other cafés in the city have been adopting, I'd be thrilled. I'm excited to have a Ritual option that doesn't require me traipsing to the Mission!
author: Kat F.

description: Cute park to sit and savor a finer cup. The baristas seem to enjoy attending to customers and the "ritual" of the pour over coffee.
author: Ria J.

description:
Good service, good coffee!  I'm glad this is literally across the street from me and I can grab a cup and walk around the neighborhood and enjoy the day with friends.  We ordered the latte, la folie and the brazilian one, which were all really good!

I think this might be my new favorite besides blue bottle!
author: Nancy S.

description: Wherever your Hayes Valley expedition takes you, beeline here for a closing caffeine and meditation.  The coffee is savory and soothing.  The staff friendly and adroit.  A parade of humanity drifts by, and it's a long sequence from a Fellini film, in color.
author: Mutant O.

description: How long have they been in Hayes Valley? SO happy they are! The coffee is fresh and has great flavor. Friendly staff and meat wagon next door.. perks! :)
author: Bree G.

description:
I am an overworked, broke, caffeine addicted law student. So when I decide to drop $4 on a cappuccino, the espresso better be strong and the milk steamed to foamy perfection. 

Ritual is just as good as the blue bottle coffee cafe around the corner with a single PLUS, they take card. If you are anything like me and despise the use of dirty cash monies, Ritual Coffee Roasters is an addiction I can accept.
author: Joann A.

description:
Look, I don't love Ritual coffee. I want to. I mean, their staff is friendly, their ambiance is fun and comfortable, and their cafe is a scene. But it comes down to this: every time I try to like their coffee, convincing myself that my memory is faulty or that my last meh experience must have been a fluke/my own damn fault, the same thing happens: I get a cup of coffee that tastes like char. Bleh. 

I know these folks know what they are doing, and I think this is just a matter of different stylistic preferences. But I'd just rather give my coffee bean money to Four Barrel, or Blue Bottle, or Sightglass, or the many other Bay Area coffees that don't taste like coal to me.

I would and do come here to hang out - like I said, they have a nice atmosphere, and its the preferred hang of plenty of my Ritual addict friends. But I might end up ordering a tea.
author: Monica S.

description:
Came to this little red pop up in the hopes to taste to and savor a cup of Ritual's liquid loveliness. I came, I got, and I tasted! I ordered a sweet tooth latte which was everything but a standard cup of joe. It was flavored with some sweet notes with just enough froth on top. Prepared fast and perfect, really. 

No parking for days so I'd suggest doing a drive by with a pal while you order and they drive around the block. Pair this with some Chantal Guillon macarons around the corner and I'd say you've got yourself a better than average Sunday.
author: Stephanie H.

description: This is some great coffee when I went to get a latte. The coffee was very smooth and not bitter at all when drinking. I really enjoyed this cup of coffee and the price is not bad at all for a latte. They are very efficient with making your coffee too and do a good job on it as well. Another great coffee shop in SF, which never seems to disappoint me.
author: Spencer E.

description:
Okay. This is truly "as good as it gets!"  Five stars FOR SURE.

The drip coffees are amazing and they switch them up enough so you can try something new.  You can also always fall back on their cappuccinos which are out of this world. The cappuccino's easily merit Ritual five stars, the--super friendly, extra approachable--staff make me wish I could give them 6.

Don't think, just go.
author: Matthew J.

description:
The coffee is whatever. I tell myself the price is fair because the beans are probably expensive and fair trade, blah blah blah.

The servers give you attitude.

Most importantly: when paying with credit, it's done by iPad and there's an option to give a tip between $0-$3. IT'S SET TO $2 BY DEFAULT!!!! Most people don't even notice that option. You end up paying $5 for a $3 cup of coffee.

I hope you choke on your expensive beans; you guys are a bunch of crooks.
author: Anton S.

description:
Not only is this the best coffee you can get from a random stand next to a park, it's the best coffee you can get in the city. 

+1 for espresso that's full-bodied and sweet, even without milk or sugar

+1 for barista that offered to remake my macchiato after he noticed what was quite possibly a coffee grind (it wasn't, it was an air bubble)

+1 for accepting Square

+1 for the super nice baristas that walk the fine line between friendly and chatty (especially when they know you're on your first caffeine dose of the day)

+1 for delicious drip in addition to the espresso drinks...

Double high-fives. This place is my favorite, nothing like sipping some warm coffee in the chilly SF morning air.
author: Allison S.

description:
Latte was lukewarm, at first I thought it was me but the barista did heat 
my own cup. Definitely not at the 160-180 degree mark, sorry if you're going to purport yourself as at the top of the game you have to at least  get the basics down.  

and the service, after waiting at the counter I finally had to speak up and ask if I was out of line?I was "schooled" that in the future I should approach from the side of the barista and then pay the cashier.

Like that, "in the future"

Cibo in Sausalito could teach these folks a lesson
author: KEITH D.

description: It doesn't get much better than Ritual for coffee in SF, and I love the awesome stand surrounded by awesome food trucks smack dab in the middle of Hayes Valley.  Delicious, caffeinated, outdoorsy bliss!
author: Bridget B.

description:
I'm more of a Philz kinda gal, so Ritual was a-ok. Kinda similar to Blue Bottle, but not as strong. Since they do make everything to order, it takes a while to get your coffee.

This wasn't my problem, but I noticed that the barista messed up an order and didn't even apologize or offer to fix the order for the customer. He just kinda said he messed up and asked if it was ok if they just took it. Glad it wasn't me because I would've been pissed!
author: Miss H.

description: With your awesome drink in hand, sit down in the park and enjoy some fine people and dog watching!
author: Grace K.

description:
While I wouldn't call myself a coffee snob (just yet), I'd like to think that I've had enough of my fair share of SF coffee experiences to know what makes a great cuppa coffee. 

I found Ritual while on a quest for unique, nitrogen-blasted ice cream at Smitten. Being the skeptic that I was, I merely peeked at Ritual's kiosk and went on my merry way to what was comfortable and familiar to me; Blue Bottle.  

After countless trips to Hayes Valley, I finally decided to give Ritual a try. I had seen a friend of mine checking in to this place on Facebook, which of course convinced me to give it a go. 

The staff was pleasant and so were their patrons. The soy latte I ordered was a bit underwhelming as far as mouthfeel, but did not disappoint as far as the quality of the coffee. I was pleasantly surprised with its tastiness and how long my caffeine buzz lasted throughout the day (and night!)

I will definitely be coming back here. Ritual is perfect for sipping while enjoying an unusually warm SF summer morning

.
author: Mary S.

description:
Great little outdoor spot. Very cute setup that makes their entire shop look mobile (or maybe it is?). Any time I'm in the area, I'll be back. 

If you can't decide as I couldn't, ask, the barista made a fabulous recommendation.
author: Frankie S.

description: These people are the nicest ever!!  Love getting coffee here because they are so nice AND my macchiato was amazing!  It was a REAL macchiato!  Since we moved to Hayes valley this is our go to place.  Usually I just get the americano. Very well done and not bitter like some other places!    Bottom line nice people
author: Leslie M.

description:
The staff are all very friendly and I enjoy the sunny outdoor atmosphere. 

There coffee descriptions are actually pretty accurate.  Be aware that the drip coffee takes a good bit of time to make but it is worth it!

Sometimes you can find a food truck (rotating vendors) next door around lunch time (and also maybe in the evening?) so you may be able to eat on their patio furniture or in the small park across the street.
author: Leuwam T.

description:
I come here a lot for my weekend caffeine ritual.   The coffee is excellent but not as strong as Peet's.  However, I like to support local businesses so it's a all good.  

What i like:  The amazing scones that go with my latte.
What I don't like:  The slow employees.  Time is precious people.
author: Truong P.

description:
Two additional trips to Ritual.  I think they're getting the memo on being snotty because they have been way different in attitude.

Good for them.  Welcome to the neighborhood.
author: Kurt F.

description: Best soy latte in town - period
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
These guys really care about what they are doing with coffee. I visited the warehouse where the beans are roasted a couple of months ago and was impressed at how much time and care they put into their beans. Likewise you can really taste the love in each cup of brew and this lil' trailer is no exception. A lil' bit of seating outside, cool electronic iPad tab-thingy (you can create a username and just add drinks to your tab via your cc! Hello 2011!), and a chill atmosphere.

The drip is my fav. My latte love was stolen yesterday by Caffe Trieste. But RCR drip is bomb!
author: Leigh W.

description: Woohoo! This is another great addition to The Proxy that sits back to back with Smitten Ice cream. Now you don't have to hop over to the Mission to get your cup and it's great being able to have your drink in sunny Patricia Green. Too bad Ritutal still hasn't grown on me though and Blue Bottle is just around the corner....
author: Jennifer W.

description: I tried the hand poured drip coffee on Valencia and I wasn't wow by it. This time, I ordered a cappuccino and it was warm and just didn't have that bold kick I wanted. I have came to the conclusion that Ritual is not my cup of coffee.
author: Kien M.

description:
I admit it - I cheat on BB with R.
Especially if I peak around the corner and there is line at BB.

Espresso, cappuccino - all are good.
I like the fact that Ritual drip more than one origin of coffee. Although I have to admit that I end-up getting the cheapest one anyway  ($5 for a drip seems to be too much). :)

I did not encounter any of the snootiness or attitude as other reviewers.
I like guys who work weekday mornings.
author: BO P.

description:
Their coffee tastes really great! I love the flavor and how they drip the coffee individually.

Price is a bit high but I rather spend $3-4 on something good than on starbucks/peets. If i'm in the area I come here because it hasn't disappointed me yet!
author: Tiffany L.

description: One of the best lattes I've ever had...need I say more? ;-)
author: Michelle O.

description:
One of the better cups of coffee in Hayes Valley, and much better atmosphere and service than the unnamed place around the corner on Linden. The baristas here remember me ever since a woman told me she could get me a job doing architectural drafting during a conversation here. I have never heard back about the job, alas. The familiarity is really nice, though, having only lived here a few months and not really knowing many people.

The coffee is really good, too, and brewed to order per cup. I did, however, find myself once exclaiming, "I can't believe I paid $5 for a cup of coffee!" The reason for 4 stars instead of 5 is that the $3 cup was better than the $5 one.

Also, they take credit cards, yay!
author: Jamie G.

description:
Excellent espresso, really cool space.  Less snob factor than their competitors (they carry soy and 1%!).  

Only drawback is the small case of baked goods, but there's a La Boulage across the street so no biggie.
author: E O.

description: I've been traveling the West Coast trying dozens of "famous" coffee roasters and this was by far the worst experience I have had. Don't get me wrong, Ritual beans deserve their reputation, and I have been to many other establishments where they were expertly prepared (or at least had some love in them). But this was abysmal. The baristas were subpar, and beyond that rude. Rude baristas can ruin even fantastic coffee, but when they can barely bring the flavor out of a roast like Ritual's they are failing completely. I seriously felt like I walked into a comedy sketch making fun of snooty hipster Baristas. Apparently it's hard to make a decent espresso when you are busy holding your overly pierced nose that far in the air.
author: Hannah M.

description: Actually I wanted to go to Blue Bottle Coffee but it was already closed. I read some good reviews for this one and it turned out I was just seated in front. I'd recommend to taste the black coffee with the v60 without sugar or milk, you will notice it's not that bitter. There is a square in front of this place, so just grab a seat and enjoy your coffee while listening street music.
author: Sergio G.

description:
Can't believe I had the good fortune to move in just around the corner from this little Ritual outpost! I've had a lot of coffee in my life from many an SF roaster (drip and espresso) and I've never found a business that takes such care and pride in the quality and presentation of their product. 

Yes, I will agree with other reviewers that this is not the place to go if you want your coffee ready before you're even finished paying. But I'd rather have my coffee made to order, and waiting for 5 minutes is not a high price to pay when you walk away with this coffee in hand. The small crew of baristas is the most passionate and knowledgeable that I've ever encountered. It's my favorite coffee in my favorite spot in San Francisco - I come here for the experience AND the superior product, and can't take enough friends here.
author: Annemarie E.

description: I love Ritual. I always get little hearts on my lattes and I fall in love every time. I've heard that their coffee is more acidic than most but I think it's perfect. This location is so cute and unexpected too. Great place to stroll around or sit and enjoy amazingly fancy coffee in a beautiful neighborhood in SF. And Annie works at this location too. She is the best!
author: Amy W.

description:
Mind blowing ritual. OK coffee.

Their technique has been justifiably praised. Fair trade and environmentally friendly sourcing. Extensive barista training. Thirty steps just to make an espresso. Drip made one cup at a time. Watching them brew my Costa Rican Monte Copey was a lesson in caffeinated passion.

Unfortunately the end product was just so so. Was expecting hints of vanilla and peaches as described on the menu. It was just black and strong. And not cheap for $4, but you are paying to do what's right.

Support the cause even if the product wasn't as good as the process.
author: Jason B.

description:
Coffee is legit.  
$4 well spent on good coffee and bonding with random strangers as we all wait for our fix.  Don't let the unfamiliar setting of a empty parking lot and odd stand deter you from quite possibly a ridiculously good cup of joe.
I miss you Soledad coffee.
author: Carol V.

description: I always stop here if I'm in Hayes valley. I usually get a macchiato. The espresso is perfect. Doesn't leave a bad taste in your mouth and goes down smooth. Whenever I have friends coming into the city I usually try to find a ritual to take them to. Stop by their container if you're ever around!
author: J L.

description: This is good coffee. I go here when I'm too lazy to walk to blue bottle, which is about half the time. Staff is friendly at quick. I like their caps and Americanos and the cold brew is great on a hot day. Baked goods are pretty great as well! What else can I say? Its coffee.
author: Michael V.

description: Saw a bug crawling through their pastries and brought it to the notice of the person at the counter. He seemed aware of it apparently and yet couldn't be bothered to do anything about it.  Bad hygiene and an I don't care attitude?
author: Rita S.

description:
Very nice baristas, ok coffee, annoying clientele. Not sure what the hype is about this place. The coffee is rather tart. They use the standard 'pour over' method, which is what I have been doing since Melitta sold the cones and filters in the '80s. Like any other filtered coffee, it lacks the richness that coffee oils impart, because the filters filter out those oils. The lines are long and other customers tend to just stand in the way while waiting for their coffees to be poured. The stand is in the middle of a parking lot with only a few outdoor seats. It is around the corner from Smitten, also packed with hipsters trying to get freeze dried ice cream. The beans themselves are splendid. I buy them separately to make French press style coffee.

Oh, and the descriptions of their coffees are laughable. I mean really, 'candy green apple' with hints of chocolate?? Really, this is coffee, not wine.
author: Dd d.

description:
This place is everything I love and hate about Hayes Valley and maybe San Francisco in the bigger scheme.

So it's great to have this former parking lot converted into an open air space to enjoy coffee but then there seems to be a wandering crowd of lost goons hovering in front of the entire counter.  Which brings me to one suggestion:

Signage.

Yeah I know we're going minimalist but a simple "Order Here" sign would be welcome and certainly would help the newbs figure out where they should begin a line.  Maybe even a request to step to the back would help said people from stacking up in front of where everybody else is trying to get their coffee.

The other gripe comes in that the drip coffee takes forever.  Not because it's drip coffee, mind you, but organizationally things are a bit off.  My pals on Valencia seem to be able to crank out my joe pretty swiftly regardless of crowd.  Here it took at least 15 minutes if not longer with the same amount of staff.  I actually nearly bailed on my order because it was taking so long.

The coffee thankfully is still top notch.  I still love ya Ritual, let's just try to be faster than Blue Bottle, yeah?
author: Steven R.

description:
The iced coffee is quite tasty and I had an apricot pastry called the "galette" that really hit the spot in the morning before work. They also have Square.

Plus, the baristas are extremely friendly.
author: Leigh D.

description: Coffee was good.  It was a nice little popup place with a central location.  The staff was very friendly and attentive.  The coffee for purchase was a little on the pricey side, but I bought some anyway.
author: J R.

description: Too cool for a traditional brick and mortar cafe, this Ritual location is reminiscent of a shipping container offering great coffee and some limited outdoors seating (public benches and a small grassy area are directly across the street). Easily ranking among my favorite coffee roasters, Ritual offers smooth and delicious pour overs, espresso, and cold brews. If you're a coffee snob, Ritual should be a rite of passage.
author: Ryan S.

description:
Had a drip coffee this morning. It was excellent compared to most coffee you can get most places, but not as good as Blue Bottle, which unfortunately for this Ritual location is less than a half block away. 

I can't believe I just wrote that. It makes me sound like a total coffee snob. I'm really not that picky about my coffee, either...... Well I guess now I am. 

Bottom line: very good coffee here.
author: A A.

description: When I first moved to this neighborhood I was a big fan of Blue Bottle. While I still appreciate it (especially their New Orleans iced), I've been drinking Ritual lately. I appreciate that they have different price levels on their drip coffees, and that the beans rotate every few weeks or so. The staff is always really friendly too!
author: Mike C.

description: Good coffee and service is pleasant. They do take their time, but on a relaxing weekend it is perfect. Nice coffee.
author: Alice T.

description:
Please, oh please for the love of all that's holy come to Chico, ca.

Im dyin' here, man!

John, Ive been a fan for years, and now that Im in Butte county, Im at a loss for a decent cup. Taking a train ride back monthly just to get a hold of some Ritual at the Little Bird. Its getting pricey.

Think it over?

Heart you guys... Mean it...
author: Sam P.

description:
Try: Caramelized Coconut Macaroon

Love the service and people.

Their food truck was at the Eat Real Festival in Oakland this past weekend and I was insanely thankful for their presence. After volunteering all day, I was exhausted and the site of their red truck made me leap for joy. =) 

This was the first time I tried their sweets from the Black Jet Baking Co. The Caramelized Coconut Macaroon was so good. Buttery, perfect balance of caramel, sweetness, and toastiness. Amazing.
author: Sue Y.

description:
hayes valley pod.  3-4 humans behind the bar.  11:30ish in the late morning.  i'm one of only two patrons waiting for our drink. 
on the luke-side of lukewarm latte.  how does that work?  fail.
author: FancyPant S.

description: Really good coffee, solid smooth with lots of depth. As is the mission hipsta vibe going around here. Didn't have a "I would like to sit and chill" vibe for me here though, so I  be taking my coffee to go.
author: Dang L.

description: Short hair dark headed barista refused to serve me a coffee with a shot of espresso in it. He said there was a strict policy against it. Such policies seem a bit OTT. Esp since there wasn't anyone else in line for a drink. I get it, my drink of choice offends your delicate barista sensibilities. And then when he refused and I said ok nevermind, he and the other bearded barista laughed at me as I walked off. Well I'll be taking my offensive order elsewhere. It's a bummer, I was hoping to find my new fave coffee stand. Meh.
author: C. B. Z.

description: A very nice espresso.  Medium bodied, and a little brighter than I usually like.  But very well pulled.  I like the pop up container it sits in here in Hayes Valley.  All of it may have been shown up by the Oreo made in house.
author: Porca M.

description:
i love ritual. their mochas make me smile.

though sometimes i feel like the people behind the counter shun me for tainting coffee with chocolate. 

i don't care. i love mochas and mochas love me.
author: Regina C.

description:
Maybe they can make a decent cup of coffee, but my hot chocolate was just disgusting. It tasted like Hershey's syrup!!
Had a couple of sips and threw it away. Shame.
author: Laure b.

description: They were busy so set up a separate drip coffee station which worked perfectly for me.  No wait, and delicious coffee.  I was happy this day.
author: mike t.

description: I was excited to see a pop-up shop in Hayes Valley, so we opted to try our Ritual Coffee.  The drip was a little expensive for just a cup of coffee ($4) and I would have to say I still prefer Philz or Blue Bottle more.
author: Carli F.

description: Great for outdoor seating. Staff sucked. I would recommend the thirty second walk to blue bottle for more flavor depth and better cust service if you have a question or are interested in beans or swag
author: Tess G.

description: It's good, but not sure what the hype is about.  I wouldn't go out of my way to get a latte from here.  The people/service were kind of slow, but everyone was very nice.  Still.... what's the hype all about?  Hipsters be hypin errrythanggg these days.
author: Anna T.

description: Rich flavorful coffee and friendly people.  When the sun shines this place is great as you sit outside and enjoy the weather. Not sure if I'd go there in the rain
author: Vivek V.

description: I love coffee and have turned into one of "those people" but I am okay with it.  Ritual is my favorite coffee of all of the "third wave" spots because the coffee is smooth and has a great flavor.  Also, the staff is not pretentious like at most of the other places.  I try to get to the pop-up on Octavia as often as I can.
author: Ravi R.

description: Ritual coffee was ok.  The actual coffee store is more like a stand and its adorable.  Its an outside walk up counter that shares a back wall with smitten ice cream.  Its a great place to grab a coffee drink and sit in the park, and if you are lucky watch the bulldog who skateboards whiz by.  The staff was extremely friendly, the prices affordable, but the coffee itself...eh.  Full disclaimer...I ordered an ice coffee so perhaps the regular coffee is much better and I would be open to giving that a try.  But the coffee tasted weak and watered down.  Honestly I threw it out after drinking about a quarter...and that is something I never do....and though I am not opposed to returning, with the blue bottle stand a block away and grove down the street...I don't know under what circumstances I'd be back...
author: Kierstan G.

description:
I can't believe how unbelievably terrible the work ethics of these old fartin hipsters trying to hold on strongly to some idea of cool they were never able to experience in their younger years..
nearing 40yr old baristas being snobbish towards their customers..lol
are they smoking angel dust or something?
was my first visit today and there was no communication while i waited for someone to not just look at me but to say something..
afterwards, their responses to my questions were all like shrug offs...and they were rude to my co worker.

wtf...
people should treat one another with respect they would want and especially when you are working..
i'm at a loss for words but i swear, i wanted to throw my coffee at them haha
tip jar?
PLahhh!
author: Suzie P.

description: When you don't feel like Blue Bottle, Ritual is as good, if not BETTER, substitute/replacement.
author: Dorothy L.

description:
Best danish ever
Cappuccino was good though a little light for my taste
Decaf coffee had an odd sourish taste
author: mike p.

description:
Dabbled in Ritual yesterday morning to spread the love around the local economy -- I am a daily Blue Bottle drinker and I felt slightly OK about it since my roommate was buying.

Never again.

We walk up to order 2 drip coffees and a shot.  The following ensues:

(walk up to coffee dripping in cool copper holster thing)

me: 2 coffees and a shot please

older woman who seemed to be in position of power announces to me and the few customers in front of and back of me: actually, we're not dripping coffee right now.  we're still getting our feet wet and tamping down the grinder and water to make sure it tastes right.

me: hm, ok.  well I'll just try one shot of each of the single-origin espressos.

them: actually, we're only pulling one today.

me: ok...i'll have two shots of that.

them (aside): Lori? (hands a drip coffee to someone...)

my roommate: so, are you guys going to have coffee today?

them: yeah we'll have it today, just not right now.

me (under my breath) : what the fuck is going on here? (at this point a few people leave the line)

(I get my espresso and enjoy it on the complimentary chairs while laughing at the absurdity of it all)

SCENE.

The espresso was actually pretty good, so I was going to let everything slide.  But then they started taking orders for and making more drip coffees.  For the people right behind us. In fact, the younger girl working asked my roommate if she could "get anything going" while we were waiting for our espresso...seemingly implying that right after we were told no drips that we could have a drip (?)

I have no idea what was going on here, but I intend never to find out.  My best guess is some kind of passive aggressiveness from the boss-lady about a bad drip one of the new employees made.  There's 4 places pour-over dripping in a one-block radius guys -- get yourselves together before you open up.  They also haven't figured out that the knee level pastry display is not exactly eye-catching (read: visible to adults).

Go to the blue bottle kiosk (http://www.yelp.com/biz/blue-bottle-coffee-co-san-francisco-5) down the alley -- they are absolutely lovely people.  If the line is long there check out the Four Barrel drip at Seesaw (http://www.yelp.com/biz/seesaw-san-francisco).
author: Andrew C.

description: It is a nice cute place - love stopping there for a morning cup of tea or coffee on my way to work! when the weather is sunny and warm - it is even better!
author: Nastia R.

description: I'm always game for a great cup of coffee (especially not Starbucks). Nice little outdoor place in Hayes Valley. They have a few picnic table to sit. The coffee is nice and smooth (though I prefer a little strong (Blue Bottle) but that is just my preference).  Still a great place for a cup of coffee especially after the meal at the Biergarten and the ice cream at Smitten!
author: Jay S.

description: Sweet tooth expresso.  You can definitely tase the sweet, but it's a little too sour.
author: Byron L.

description: And you complain about Starbucks being expensive? There is no question that Ritual Roasters makes a damn fine cup of coffee.  And the soy cappuccino I am drinking right now is buttery soft with a luxurious lingering on the palette. But I just paid about five bucks for two shots and a splash of soy. They didn't charge for the sweetener though. It is great coffee but how can you expect to patronize a business consistently if it is so expensive? Yeah the quality is better than Starbucks and frankly the line is long on a dreary Sunday morning, but to go to this place a few times a week would add up quickly.  I guess you pay for the hipster appeal as well as the tasty brews.
author: Adam E.

description: $4.00 for a luke warm cup of drip coffee...... no thank you.  $4 for a cup of coffee?????????  COFFEEEEE!!!
author: Dan S.

description: really hard to find parking space in Hayes valley. so come early
author: Momo G.

description:
First Impressions: 3/5. The lack of pretentiousness of this little Ritual Coffee Roasters stand was endearing, but maybe the in-your-face red color scheme just bothered my subconscious. I know that it's part of their brand image though, so this was just my subjectivity at play this time. I did appreciate that everything (staff appearance, equipment, cleanliness) seemed to be very orderly and neat though, so yay for the appearance of a well-run stand.

Staff: 4/5. There were two people working there when my 2 other friends and I visited. The lady there greeted us warmly and proceeded to describe their unique coffee blends from different countries after we told her it was our first time. The guy there then proceeded to make our coffees and was nice enough to do some coffee foam art! (see picture :)). I always suspect it's ultimately the barista's choice when making an effort to create coffee foam art, so I'm always pleased to see it in my cup. It's definitely about appreciating the little things especially when I know the barista could've just whipped up any sort of formula & served it however he desired.

Mocha:
Bg: Since I try to only drink one cup of coffee a day on my off-days, I only had the chance to try their mocha. I knew I really should've tried their drip coffees and I was especially curious to taste Hondurian coffee beans again, but I just craved a mocha at the time. Here's the run down...
Rating: 3.5/5. My first impression of their mocha was a 2/5, but I later realized this was due to coming off the fresh trail of drinking the extra chocolatey mocha at a La Boulange the other day. Slowly sipping, I decided that this was a very well-made mocha because it's subtle and doesn't try to overwhelm you with the I'MMADEFROMCHOCOLATE/LOOKATME reaction. And if I were to drink mochas often, I think I would prefer to drink the one at Ritual more often than La Boulange's. And maybe with a more objective onset the next time I visit, I'll bump up the rating to a 4/5. It's not perfect, but it was still delicious.

Random comment: I noticed that the paper cup was completely unadorned w/ any kind of branding and in a weird way (is this how hipsters think... -__-) I appreciated it because it made them at least appear humble... making my wanting to support them as a local business.

Overall: 3.5/5 w/ great willingness for a few more chances. A friend who lives in SF swears by them, so I am open to understanding Ritual a little better.
author: F C.

description: It's a Ritual for one of the boys to get a coffee while we run back and forth between macarons and ice cream.
author: Ashly d.

description: Im not much of a coffee beast but I do like drinking coffee a few times a week so maybe I should claim ignorance on why they make iced coffee by hand which took forever.  That being said the coffee was pretty good and I would probably go back again but at least next time I know that I will be there like 10 minutes before its ready.
author: Scott G.

description: So since I've tasted Ritual's roasts in many other coffee shops I can safely say that the baristas at this Ritual location have no clue what they are doing.  In fact I had the same exact roast a week ago in a Seattle shop.  These ladies managed to take a pretty generically nice bean and made it into a generically bland espresso.  Since I can get Ritual beans in other places I would never come here again,  and would dissuade others from going as well.  They also lose a star for not having a bathroom.  And more importantly,  the people working there were rude,  wouldn't prepare just one of the 3 macchiatos I ordered the way I very nicely asked for it (I wanted the shot poured over a tiny bit of sugar). Yes all 3 were for me.  I just wanted to experience the roast in a variety of ways.  They were also generally bitchy at me and laughed at me.  That's not just unprofessional,  but very presumptuous.  For the love of God,  I'm on an espresso vacation.  I could say nastier things that are going through my head.  But all I will say is that the people working there should trek up to Slate in Seattle and learn a thing about customer service,  oh wait,  they've never even heard of it.  Good job,  fools.
author: Brenda B.

description: I've passed by the Ritual Coffee location in Hayes Valley numerous times but never when I had a coffee craving, until last week.  I was walking down Hayes Street and decided to give this place a try.  I didn't have too high of expectations since I'm not a coffee expert or anything so I ordered a medium latte 1% milk.  Again, considering I ordered a drink with low-fat milk and no sugar added I expected it to be lacking in flavor, however it had a rich, great flavor.  I ordered a medium and the price was $3.75, I thought the price was a little high considering a medium isn't very big, but it is what it is.  If I remember correctly they used organic milk so I guess that adds on a little more to the cost.  Overall, I'd go back.  oh, and they use Square on the iPad to ring you up so no need to waste paper by printing receipts.
author: Kent W.

description: Thank you Ritual -- This is the perfect location for me right between home and work. Defiantly the most delicious coffee. I felt so sneaky creeping past all the crazys who stood in line for Blue Bottle. I'm going to make sure to make ritual stops at this location.
author: Rhiana M.

description: So I have been going to Blue Bottle for a bit. This place opened around the corner. In my head I was thinking, "Dick move" but you know to business is business. Anyways I tried it out. It's pretty good. I got a cup of their Siberian and a macaroon. The coffee was pretty good. Strong but not over powering. Had some flavor to it too. The macaroon on the other hand had an awfully strange texture. Almost a little too moist but the coconut was toasted around it so good that it was all I tasted for about 15 minutes. It was great. I might just come back in the morning for one of those.
author: Greg G.

description: Wow. An excellent latte, beautifully prepared. Grab a duo cup and sit in the small seating area, or cross the bike oath and enjoy the park. Proxy is a fascinating temporary food set-up; let's hope it stays for a long time.
author: Greg P.

description: This place is kind of trendy, but for good reason.  The coffee is delicious!  Their teas are also good especially the elderflower one.  Their whole bean coffee brews great at home.  The ambiance in the coffee shop is great for hanging out, studying, or chatting with a friend.
author: Julie B.

description: The location - a popup in a shipping container in Hayes Valley is great, the coffee although not my favorite in town is solid and worth checking out. It was also nice to have a tea option. Like others have mentioned the signs can get hard to read if people are milling about the ordering area. There are a few tables nearby so you can relax over there and out of the way. Drip coffee always makes me feel a bit "watched pot" if you know what I mean. Swing around the other side to Smitten for ice cream. Nothing like hot and cold to set your teeth on fire.
author: Phoebe R.

description: Love the location and brand/look. But every time I'm a bit disappointed in the shot. Looks good and always soooper smooth but lacks the punch of bb Hayes valley or some of the sight glass blends. Will keep trying though. Love their contribution to the Hayes valley neighborhood.
author: Rachel H.

description: Best coffee in San Francisco, and an added bonus is that they already know what I want when I walk up to the counter.
author: William W.

description: I've known about Ritual for a while but just now getting around to trying it. The Libertad sold me on a return visit I tried the Sao Benedicto. Subtle, medium body. Prepared to perfection. No burnt or acidic aftertaste. Friendly prompt service. No stereotypical coffee smugness. My new fave coffee shop.
author: Quentin J.

description: I recommend this place for the environment- great place to bring a laptop and get some work done if you are lucky enough to get a seat (note: there are only outlets at one communal table for 8 people).  I was however disappointed by the coffee!  I am somewhat of a coffee snob and found their coffee barely drinkable after paying $4 for a cup.  If I go back to work, I might stick to just the pastries next time.
author: Elana R.

description: Awesome little hipster coffee spot. Drip coffee was incredible and made to order.
author: Annie H.

description: Great place for coffee in the Hayes. Get the Siberia roast- it's bold rich and intense...perfect for the New Yorker in me :)
author: Helen B.

description: Great coffee, a variety of blends, knowledge staff, and the blonde texan.
author: Cullen R.

description: Excellent coffee... but wow a cup is quite expensive.  I'd rank this place behind blue bottle (still my fave) and phil's.
author: Brian A.

description: This place has very yummy coffee. I love their lattes. The only draw back is they don't have plugs so you cant study / work on a paper.
author: casey b.

description: I really enjoyed watching the coffee brewing process. It was very scientific. Great coffee.
author: Corey B.

description: Loveeeee.  Best coffee in the city...always a consistent flavor.   Staff is fun...friendly.
author: Alejandro M.

description: A great cup of coffee.  We've been imbibing for years.  A little too much of a scene at times, but I won't ding them a star just because hipsters dig good coffee.
author: bil t.

description:
Love them. Love their Valencia branch too, but nothing compares to sipping a cappuccinno in the sun...in a park.

The baristas are really nice, and more importantly - consistent. Their coffee is always pulled the right way...
author: Ron B.

description: This espresso has a sour taste, just like red rock and blue bottle. The rest of the taste isn't good either, though.
author: Duncan T.

description: We come here usually on Saturdays with the kids . The people are super nice. The mocha is AMAZ-ING and they make a kids hot chocolate that my kids thing is the BEST ANYWHERE. They also put a little leaf or heart design on top which my kids think is so super cool. There are some chairs you can chill on outside. LOVE
author: Noelle M.

description: I used to love this place, but last time I came, I thought prices had gone crazy and my $4 capuccino was served cold. Can't blame the place for it's clientele, I guess, but defenitely not a place for me...
author: Maria M.

description: meh takes to long. not worth the wait.
author: Jake C.

description: A good place to go with your laptop and listen to good music with good coffee with friendly enough staff.
author: Peter T.

description: It's not bad - but if you're going to wait in a line that long, do it a block away at Blue Bottle
author: Jeffrey H.

description: Hands-down one of the best coffee joints in the city. Great drinks, wonderful location.
author: Mike G.

description: Great Latte. Friendly staff. Nice outdoor only seating.  Right across from a small but nice dog park and kids play park.  I didn't try any of their baked goods but coffee in their comfy outdoor chairs on a sunny day is tuff to beat.
author: Tod S.

description: A choice between a $5, a $4, or $3 dollar cup of coffee. Okay, I guess this will be a really good cup of coffee,  These guys pride themselves on their knowledge.  Well, SOMETHING went wrong. The cup of coffee was like bitter water. It looked like they used about 8 beans to make 12 oz. of coffee. I literally threw it away. It was that bad. And it made me really mad. Not what I want from a cup of coffee first thing in the morning! Three dollars down the drain.
author: Doug N.

description: Ritual Coffee need to put out trash cans for their customers. It is not enough to say "the architects" don't want trash collection in the common spaces, it's a matter of community responsibility.   While as a long term resident of Hayes Valley, it's great to see new businesses in the community, the people you serve have no interest in keeping our little park free of coffee debris.  And no, they are not going to bring their emptry paper cups back to you to dispose of.  Please use some common sense here and put out trash bins.  The architects have been contacted and there will be discussions.  In the meantime, a trash bin of your own, please.
author: Emerald O.

description: i love the location and interesting design of the shop, but coffee is ok, not that impressive
author: Michelle K.
